reviewText: This collection of movies from the 70s is a hit and miss grab bag, and make no mistake it's mostly miss.Sure there are quite a few stars like Cosby, Bronson, Field, Burton and even Spacek but what you have here are their lesser movies that never really had that much impact the first time around.So we're talking B movies, failed movies, TV movies, and failed TV Pilots.  Even the TV movies are the 2nd rate & less memorable ones that you can't recall from back-in-the-day no matter how hard you try.Out of 50 in the batch there are only about a dozen that are worth seeing.>>But the biggest issue here is the poor picture quality!Most movies are not even up to VHS standard but were dubbed from noisy, dirty and carved up old film. Some of the splicing is brutal and there are massive color shifts from splice to splice.So you have to ask yourself:  Is this worth wading through the maze for a dozen poor video quality flicks (out of 50) for $10 or $12 bucks?(That's about a buck a movie, If you pay full price it's over $2)If you think so, go for it.....
summary: A Rock Bottom Price for 50 Movies...BUT~~~
Title: N/A

reviewText: My husband and I are not finding anything interesting to watch on TV anymore, so we were searching for some good retro entertainment.  These movies hold your attention without any of the gore, sex and violence so prevalent on TV today.  We've only watched two so far, but they were well worth the price and we are looking forward to many more hours of family entertainment.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Higher number of good (or at least semi-good) films here than in other Mill Creek collections, plus the picture quality is generally very acceptable and the menu screen is fun. One major complaint: why is Wanted: Babysitter in black & white when the movie was shot in color?
summary: One of the better Mill Creek Collections

reviewText: You will love this collection if you like 1970's films. It was great for me as I got to see some rare ones I hadn't seen before. The Klansman with Linda Evans, Death Scream AKA The Deadly Trap with Barbara Parkins, The Concrete Cowboys with Barbara Mandrell and Morgan Fairchild, and They Call It Murder with Nita Talbot.

reviewText: Great retrospective of the 70's with 50 films from that era at a price that can't be beat...and the quality is not bad.
summary: Great collection at a great price

reviewerName: Michael Noga "Jumping kings and making Haste ...
reviewText: I liked the 70s as far as films go. I think it was the last decade that the Big Studios did any kind of real experimentation with their films. Some of those experiments were wildly successful while some were spectacular failures.HOW AWFUL ABOUT ALLAN:  Anthony Perkins finds himself once again as a troubled young man with crippling mental health issues. Guilt over possibly toasting his father like a marshmallow sends him into a state of psychosomatic blindness. After  a decade in an asylum, he returns home to his sister. But the family reunion has to wait because shortly after his arrival, Anthony fears that someone is trying to kill him. Is his life in jeopardy, or is he slipping back down into madness?EVEL KNIEVEL:  Professional Tanner George Hamilton was not the best choice to play death-defying  Evel Knievel, but the movie is hardly a documentary.  It does have a certain spark though, and captures the baseless optimism of the 70s pretty well.COP IN BLUE JEANS: This is the classic American "cop who plays by his own rules" movie but seen through the eyes of an Italian studio. This puts an interesting perspective on things as the director likes to inject a little political commentary into the mix of high tension violence and gritty urban reality. You've also got Jack Palance as a vicious crime lord and that's always worth a view.STUNTS: When a stuntman is killed on location, his brother steps in to take his place so he can find out what really happened . There's a creepy special effects guy who looks guilty once the bodies start to pile up and a sexy female reporter who gets more of a story than she bargained for. It's action-packed.TO ALL MY FRIENDS ON SHORE: Bill Cosby changes gears from comedian to serious actor in this drama about a family struggling hard to climb out of a ghetto.  Cosby produced and wrote the music for this poignant little slice of life as well.  I liked it.THE WEREWOLF OF WASHINGTON: Basically a werewolf bites a reporter who then lurks around the Great Halls of the nation's capitol. It may have been funny and outrageous political satire in its day but it falls flat today.THE LAST OF THE BELLES: This one is based on the F. Scott Fitzgerald story of how he met his wife while he was in the Army.  It's an interesting story but the execution is Meh.WAR OF THE ROBOTS: Ah now this is a crappy movie. Taken seriously it has no redeeming qualities. The DVD may even require some kind of warning label. However, as fodder for sarcastic commentary, it's hard to top.  WOTR is an Italian sci-fi that wants to rip-off Star Wars but it does this so poorly I can't be sure. If you're viewing it without the benefit of a few good friends and a few more good beers I'd recommend watching the MST3k version.CONGRATULATIONS, IT'S A BOY! : This is a light-weight comedy about what happens when swinging man-about-town Bill Bixby learns he has a teen-age son. It's pretty shallow fluff but if you like Bixby or just want something frothy and unchallenging then you could do worse.CRYPT OF THE LIVING DEAD:  This is a vampire movie about a vampire queen named....Hannah. ,,,,,Hannah? Nope.THE GUN AND THE PULPIT: A gun slinging killer takes on the identity of a dead preacher in order to hide from The Law. It has some decent humor and characterizations.
summary: A mixed bag of movies, some are groovy and a few are reall bummers, man!
